awd_titl_txt: UNS:  Engineered Nanomaterial Impact on Long-Term Stability of MSW Landfill and Leachate Treatment Pond Geomembrane Liners
awd_abstract_narration:
1510869
Berge 

As engineered nanomaterial-containing products reach the end of their useful life, they will likely reside in municipal solid waste landfills. Work conducted in the principal investigator's (PI's) laboratory at the University of South Carolina suggests that the mobility of carbon nanotubes, examples of engineered nanomaterials, may be significant in waste environments containing "mature" leachate (consisting primarily of humic acid). The main goal of this research is to conduct experiments and perform molecular modeling simulations to understand the implications associated with engineered nanomaterial-geomembrane interactions in municipal solid waste landfills.

Engineered nanomaterial production continues to increase: therefore it is inevitable that engineered nanomaterial-containing products/wastes will end up in landfills. Unfortunately, there are no processes or research to evaluate whether currently designed and operating landfills and leachate treatment/storage ponds can adequately manage/contain these materials. Of particular importance is the understanding of how engineered nanomaterials may interact with the geosynthetics present in the liners. This work will elucidate the impact of engineered nanomaterials on high-density polyethylene geomembranes and importantly, how they may influence geomembrane durability/service lives. This research is transformative in that it is the first study in which engineered nanomaterial-high-density polyethylene liner interactions will be explored. Results will provide necessary information to assess whether current solid waste management processes are adequate to safely manage/contain such wastes. The research results will be widely disseminated via presentations and publications. This project is guided by the hypothesis that engineered nanomaterials will influence long-term stability of geomembranes by increasing antioxidant release/depletion. The nature of engineered nanomaterial influences on geomembranes are dependent on material application (e.g., landfill bottom liner or leachate storage pond) and environmental conditions (e.g., oxygen presence). The specific objectives of this work are: (1) Elucidate how selected engineered nanomaterials influence polymer oxidation, antioxidant diffusion, and subsequent changes in mechanical behavior of high-density polyethylene liners; (2) Understand how engineered nanomaterial surface chemistry influences polymer oxidation and antioxidant diffusion; and, (3) Perform molecular level simulations to calculate adsorption/partitioning coefficients, quantify diffusion coefficients, and calculate reaction kinetics for oxidation reactions, and develop a process model to quantify the effects of engineered nanomaterials on antioxidant depletion in high-density polyethylene liners. The PI is committed to promoting teaching, training, and learning while conducting this research. The broader impacts plan is comprised of three components: (1) K-12 outreach; (2) undergraduate research experiences for underrepresented populations in engineering; and, (3) doctoral student mentoring. It is anticipated that a large population of potential future engineers and scientists can be reached through these planned activities.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The overall focus of this grant was to understand implications associated with interactions between engineered nanomaterials (ENMs) and antioxidants found in high-density polyethylene (HDPE) geomembranes used in municipal solid waste (MSW) landfill bottom lining systems and in the lining systems of leachate collection and storage ponds. These geomembranes play a critical role in creating impermeable barriers between the landfill/leachate and the surrounding ground, thus protecting the subsurface from landfill-related groundwater contamination. These commercially available geomembranes are expected to remain effective over long periods of time and, because of this, contain antioxidants to help protect them from oxidation that may ultimately result in system failure. The main goal of this project was to conduct laboratory-scale experiments and perform molecular modeling simulations to understand how the presence of ENMs in landfill leachate may influence antioxidant migration and/or depletion from these geomembranes.

To accomplish this, a series of laboratory-scale experiments and molecular modeling simulations were conducted. Key results from this work include:

(1)   There appears to be a disconnect between currently reported antioxidant migration and release mechanisms described based on laboratory-scale testing and those elucidated from molecular-scale modeling of the system in this work. Results from work conducted in this study suggest the mechanisms associated with antioxidant migration and release from HDPE geomembranes depends on HDPE properties, particularly density. The extent of local swelling of the HDPE during high temperature accelerated aging tests dictate the fate of the antioxidants during the test. When the geomembrane contains significant amorphous regions (e.g., low densities), antioxidant diffusion is possible. However, in geomembranes containing limited amorphous regions, antioxidant depletion/release is likely controlled by antioxidant hydrolysis and/or oxidation. If the geomembrane is devoid of amorphous regions (i.e., highly crystalline), antioxidant migration, depletion, and/or release is unlikely. It is critical to understand whether the evolution of amorphous regions during accelerated aging tests reflects the evolution during normal operation.

(2)   The impact of ENM presence on antioxidants in HDPE geomembranes located in the bottom lining systems of municipal solid waste landfills depends on HDPE properties (e.g., density), available ENM surface area, and affinity of the antioxidant to the HDPE geomembrane. For ENMs to play a role in this system, the geomembrane must contain sufficient amorphous regions to permit antioxidant diffusion. However, even under these conditions, the influence of ENMs on the diffusion process is likely insignificant. The influence of ENMs on the diffusion process is likely limited both by the available ENM surface area and the preferred equilibrium partitioning of the antioxidants on the HDPE compared to water.

(3)   The impact of ENMs on HDPE geomembranes found in open systems containing leachate collections/storage ponds depends on leachate composition. Results from work conducted in this project indicated that hydroxyl radical reactions with antioxidants and humic acid (HA) are faster than with HDPE.  Except for butyric acid, hydroxyl radical reactions with volatile fatty acids (VFAs) are slower than with HDPE. These results suggest that reactive oxygen species will preferentially react with humic acids that may be present in the leachate prior to reacting with the HDPE. However, if the leachate primarily consists of VFAs (e.g., acetic and propionic acid), with the exception of butyric acid, the reactive oxygen species will preferentially react with the HDPE. Therefore, HDPE is potentially vulnerable to reactive oxygen species produced from ENMs, especially in leachates primarily composed of VFAs, since antioxidants are embedded in HDPE and except when there are HA and longer chain VFAs present in solution.

This project has also made a significant impact on the teaching and training of students. This grant provided training, mentoring, and professional development for several PhD and undergraduate students and two postdoctoral associates. The results from this grant were disseminated through several conference papers and presentations. Several peer-reviewed manuscripts are currently in preparation and are anticipated to be submitted in the coming months.


Last Modified: 06/15/2022
Modified by: Nicole Berge
